Tool Call.chief_complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath for 2 days
Tool Call.history_present_illness: 45-year-old male presents with substernal chest pain that began 2 days ago. Pain is described as pressure-like, 7/10 intensity, radiating to left arm. Associated with shortness of breath on exertion and mild diaphoresis. No nausea or vomiting. Pain not relieved with rest or antacids. Patient has history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
Tool Call.physical_examination: Vital signs: BP 150/95, HR 88, RR 18, O2 sat 97% on room air. General appearance: alert, anxious, mild distress. Cardiovascular: regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally. Extremities: no edema, peripheral pulses intact.
Tool Call.assessment: Chest pain, possible acute coronary syndrome. Differential includes unstable angina, NSTEMI, or atypical presentation. Hypertension inadequately controlled.
Tool Call.plan: Order EKG, cardiac enzymes, chest X-ray. Start aspirin 325mg, nitroglycerin PRN chest pain. Cardiology consultation. Monitor in observation unit. Adjust antihypertensive medications. Patient education on cardiac symptoms and when to seek emergency care.
